message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with superficial thrombophlebitis, including pain, swelling, redness, and a cordlike feel to the affected vein. Duplex ultrasound findings further support this diagnosis. Erythema nodosum is a rash that presents in a bilateral and symmetrical manner on the lower legs, which is not consistent with the patient’s findings. Deep vein thrombosis can also present with pain and swelling, but the location of the cordlike feel is different. Varicose veins typically appear as bulging, twisting veins that can cause discomfort but do not usually present with a palpable cord.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of a tender, palpable cord on the lateral aspect of the left lower leg, with erythematous and indurated skin suggest superficial thrombophlebitis. Deep vein thrombosis would not have erythema or induration of the skin.Erythema nodosum presents with tender, erythematous nodules on the shins, and there would not be a palpable cord. Varicose veins may cause leg swelling and discomfort, but they would not present with a palpable cord.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest superficial thrombophlebitis. Deep vein thrombosis usually presents with a tender, swollen leg with palpable cords in deep veins. Erythema nodosum and varicose veins do not present with a palpable cord.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest superficial thrombophlebitis, which is inflammation and clotting in a superficial vein. The tender, palpable cord on the lateral aspect of the left lower leg and the overlying skin is erythematous and indurated suggest thrombophlebitis rather than varicose vein or erythema nodosum. Duplex ultrasound shows vascular wall thickening and subcutaneous edema support the diagnosis of thrombophlebitis, but can also be seen in deep vein thrombosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest the most likely diagnosis is superficial thrombophlebitis. Deep vein thrombosis may present with similar symptoms but would show different findings on duplex ultrasound. Erythema nodosum and varicose vein are unlikely given the presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are consistent with superficial thrombophlebitis, with a tender and palpable cord on the lateral aspect of the left lower leg, erythematous and indurated skin, and vascular wall thickening on duplex ultrasound. Deep vein thrombosis would present with pain and swelling but typically lacks the palpable cord and has different ultrasound findings. Erythema nodosum presents with painful, red nodules, typically on the lower legs, but does not have vascular wall thickening or subcutaneous edema. Varicose veins may present with pain and edema, but typically lack the palpable cord and erythematous skin findings seen in thrombophlebitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest superficial thrombophlebitis. Deep vein thrombosis is a more serious condition and usually presents with swelling of the entire limb. Erythema nodosum is a skin manifestation of a systemic disease, and varicose veins usually do not present with a tender, palpable cord. A duplex ultrasound confirms vascular wall thickening and subcutaneous edema, which is consistent with superficial thrombophlebitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including a tender palpable cord, erythema, and induration, suggest superficial thrombophlebitis. Deep vein thrombosis would have swelling and warmth but not necessarily skin changes. Erythema nodosum would have more diffuse red nodules, and varicose veins would not typically cause such significant symptoms at 11 weeks' gestation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest superficial thrombophlebitis, which is inflammation in a vein just under the skin, usually in the legs. The tender, palpable cord on the lateral aspect of the left lower leg and the overlying skin being erythematous and indurated are all characteristic of superficial thrombophlebitis. Deep vein thrombosis would present with similar symptoms but would occur in larger veins and have a higher risk of embolism. Erythema nodosum is a skin condition that presents with tender red nodules on the shins or other parts of the body, but it doesn't involve the veins. Varicose veins would present with larger protruding veins, but not necessarily the symptoms described here.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest superficial thrombophlebitis. Deep vein thrombosis would have involved a larger vein, and the symptoms would be more severe. Erythema nodosum would present with painful, red nodules on the legs, while varicose veins would not present with a palpable cord.
